ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: amazing overview on IPE literature and methodology

I learned the basic issues and approaches in cutting-edge international political economy studies. I also learned how to take a deep dive into political economy papers and critically evaluate authors' claims.

I learned an immense amount about substantive topics in IPE. I also benefited from the in-depth discussion about methodologies underpinning both contemporary and more foundational works in the subfield. The course presentations forced students to grapple with the nuances and particulars of each paper.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: very detailed discussion of papers, including methods; very engaged professor

The course allowed students to present on select papers, which facilitated deep engagement with each paper, and to take a step back to synthesize the knowledge through reading response papers. The course was excellent for both content mastery and methodological learning. One thing I wished there was more of was Professor Queralt's take on matters, or lecture-style synopsis of the way he interprets the topic or question at hand.

Strengths: -- intensive discussion regarding the articles and methods was particularly beneficial -- professor was quite engaging and provided extensive feedback on our criticisms/comments on the course readings. It was quite clear that he came prepared to have an in-depth discussion of each reading. Weaknesses: -- the small class size made the regular student presentations a bit intense in the middle of the semester, but overall, that requirement was beneficial -- wish we'd engaged with more book-length scholarship on IPE to see how political scientists craft and explore questions in a more in-depth, lengthier format

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, to anyone who is interested in political economy or international relations.
Definitely; there's much to learn substantively about IPE and cutting edge research in political science more generally.
